Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating Hydrothermal Structures by Electrical Self-potential Measurements
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the architecture of the hydrothermal system will improve interpretation of geophysical and geochemical signals, enabling a deeper understanding of volcanic processes for more effective monitoring and eruption forecasting. The results of this project have the potential to benefit monitoring and hazard mitigation efforts at active volcanoes in the United States and worldwide. In this project, the researchers will map the structure of the hydrothermal system on White Island volcano, New Zealand. The work will be carried out under the guidance of Dr. Bruce Christenson, Senior Volcanic Fluids Geochemist at GNS Science, New Zealand.

The chemistry of gases and thermal waters near the surface provides vital information about the state of the volcano and the magma below. However, these hydrothermal systems present specific challenges for volcanology, as surface waters can alter and dilute volcanic fluids and mask seismic signals that may be coming from the movement of magma at depth. There are also inherent dangers associated with volcano-hydrothermal systems, such as phreatic (steam) and phreatomagmatic (steam + magma) eruptions and contamination of fresh surface waters, all of which put local populations at risk. Understanding the structure and behaviour of these systems is critical for interpreting volcanic signals. This in turn enables better eruption forecasting to protect the lives of people living near active volcanoes. This award will support fieldwork to map the hydrothermal system on White Island, the most active volcano in New Zealand, using a method known as electrical self-potential. As thermal fluids flow through the ground, they generate minute electrical currents. By measuring the change in electrical potential along the ground, these currents can be used to effectively map the path and direction of fluid flow.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
White Island (Whakaari) is the emergent summit of a submarine stratovolcano in the Bay of Plenty, New Zealand. The island hosts a well-developed hydrothermal system, including a hyper-acidic crater lake, acid springs, and energetic fumaroles. It is the most frequently active volcano in New Zealand with multiple phreatic (steam) and phreatomagmatic (steam + magma) eruptions occurring in recent decades. The island has a history of ill-fated mining ventures, and currently sustains an important tourist economy for the town of Whakatane. Understanding flow dynamics within the hydrothermal system is critical for interpreting volcanic signals, forecasting eruptions, and ensuring the safety of the people visiting and operating near the island.

In July 2017, we undertook an electrical self-potential (SP) survey at White Island. The survey focused around the vigorously degassing Fumarole O, which is thought to represent a direct degassing conduit from the magma reservoir. We measured four linear arrays, approximately 100 meters in length, arranged in a spoke-like pattern centred around the fumarole (see Figure 1). This arrangement duplicated those of an earlier survey from September 2015, which was taken at the beginning of a major period of unrest that was marked by increased gas emissions, volcanic tremor, and ground deformation. This unrest culminated in a hydrothermal eruption a few months later. By contrast, the 2017 survey was taken during a time of relative calm, where gas flux and seismicity were at usual background levels for this volcano.

Our results show a marked reversal in polarity between the 2015 and 2017 surveys (Figure 1), suggesting a change in the fluid flow regime in response to volcanic unrest. Fluid isotopic data from Fumarole 0 during the times of study reveals an expansion of a hot, liquid-vapor phase within the fumarole conduit during the unrest period in 2015. This is seen in the SP data as values get progressively more positive moving out from the fumarole, suggesting updraw of hot fluids from the subsurface. In contrast, during the 2017 survey, fumarole vapor was condensing and the fluid envelope around the conduit had collapsed, drawing fluids inward and downward. The SP data shows this as values get progressively more negative away from the fumarole, suggesting downflow or retraction of cooler fluids deeper into the system.

Comparison of these most recent results with those from previous SP surveys and records of unrest suggests that fluid flow conditions within the hydrothermal system do change prior to volcanic activity. The investigation is ongoing, as we attempt to establish whether a pattern exists between apparent fluid flow regimes and the onset of volcanic/hydrothermal activity.

Constraining subsurface flow dynamics within volcano-hydrothermal systems is critical for understanding volcanic processes to improve monitoring and eruption forecasting. The results of this investigation will further our understanding of changing fluid flow during periods of volcanic unrest. This work could have significant implications for interpretation of SP anomalies in active, high temperature, volcano-hydrothermal systems, thus informing use of this technique as a monitoring tool.

This work has been presented at the International Association of Volcanology and Chemistry of the Earth's Interior (IAVCEI) Cities on Volcanoes 10 conference, Naples, Italy in September 2018. It will be submitted for peer-reviewed publication later this year and will include GNS Science collaborators as co-authors. The project has facilitated collaboration between a female PhD student at Drexel University and leading researchers at GNS Science, New Zealand. Travel to GNS labs in Wellington has strengthened an important professional relationship and allowed access to much-needed mentorship for the student investigator.
